sponsor: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)
briefTitle: Anti-HIV Drug Regimens and Treatment-Switching Guidelines in HIV Infected Children
officialTitle: A Phase II/III Randomized, Open-Label Study of Combination Antiretroviral Regimens and Treatment-Switching Strategies in HIV-1-Infected Antiretroviral Naive Children Between 30 Days and 18 Years of Age

interventions.name: NRTIs (ABC, FTC, FTC/TDF, 3TC, 3TC/AZT, d4T, TDF, ddC, AZT)
otherNames: 2 NRTIs/PI, change@viral load 1000 copies/ml or higher
2 NRTIs/PI, change@viral load 30,000 copies/ml or higher
2 NRTIs/NNRTI, change@viral load 1000 copies/ml or higher
2 NRTIs/NNRTI, change@viral load 30,000 copies/ml or higher

interventions.name: NNRTIs (EFV, NVP)
otherNames: 2 NRTIs/NNRTI, change@viral load 1000 copies/ml or higher
2 NRTIs/NNRTI, change@viral load 30,000 copies/ml or higher

interventions.name: PIs (AMP, IDV, LPV/r, NFV, SQV, RTV)
otherNames: 2 NRTIs/PI, change@viral load 1000 copies/ml or higher
2 NRTIs/PI, change@viral load 30,000 copies/ml or higher

summary:
Little is known about what treatment combinations are best for HIV infected children. This study examined the long-term effectiveness of different anti-HIV drug combinations in children and strategies for switching treatment if the first treatment does not work. The study enrolled children who had not previously taken anti-HIV medication. Participants in this study were recruited in the United States, South America and Europe.

Some European children may also enroll in a substudy that will observe changes in body fat in children taking anti-HIV medications.

primaryOutcome.measure: Change in Viral Load Measured in log10 HIV-1 RNA Copies/ml
primaryOutcome.timeFrame: Baseline visit and 4 years after Study Entry
